content.description: I put anchors on this line but never sent it clean so didn't make a plaque or name it. Mostly tips crack. It's probably 12-
Ascend a corner up a wide variety of 5.10 climbing.  Not the prettiest route on the block, but is fun.
content.protection: You can place a little of everything, but may not need more than doubles.
content.location: Left side of the huge corner/alcove near the prow.  Just left of the shorter routes: Chota Boy and My Party.  From Imagine, descend down fallen pillar on the slope, underneath In and Out, and back up to a wide open flatter area.

content.description:
2 nice looking pitches, typical of Indian Creek I still only did the first one.

Start with heads up maneuvering up somewhat broken rock. When you gain the splitter it's one move of ring locks until you're in the handcrack, which is longer and more strenuous than it looks.
content.protection: Smaller stuff for the start, then doubles or triples of #2 and #3 BD C4s.
content.location: The start of this pitch is easily identifiable by where the trail goes between the wall and the prominent mini block/tower (maybe 20' tall).

content.description: This is essentially a much easier version of Layaway Plan.  Fingers and thin hands varnished corner to an undercling roof.  Watch for loose stuff at the start.  Use runners at the roof (sharp edge)  60m rope gets you down.
content.protection: Yellow alien/tcu through yellow camalot.  Many red camalots.
content.location: On the far right site of 75 Cairns Wall.  Plaque.

content.description: Not your typical Indian Creek crack in a corner. There's a hand crack on the right that intersects the offwidth/chimney on the left that makes for some odd but cool movement.
content.protection:
No large stuff required, you can get gear in the hand crack for all but the last 10ish feet. I can't remember exactly but something like triples of #1-#3 BD C4s should do it.

The anchor is 2 drilled angles and tat. Fixed biners though if memory serves.
content.location: You might not see the hand crack at first but you're sure to notice the offwidth that widens into a chimney!

content.description: A beautiful line that just feels out of reach. The crack does not begin for a good 15 feet. Either boulder up there on nothing or climb another crack to the right and traverse in on nothing. Either way, be prepared for a delicate start. The middle section has many pods to rest in and the final 20 feet are amazing .75s.
content.protection: .4 to #2. Extra on the .75 range, maybe 6 or so.
content.location: On the flat wall about 80 feet to the right of Emmanator.

content.description: A short 5.10 crack.  Traverse a low face with good feet and hands. Step up into a loose looking corner sporting a 3-4" crack.  Ascend the somewhat sandy corner crack.  Follow the  now Â±2.5" crack right, out onto the face, through a pod, to the anchors.
content.protection:
I used a handful of Camalots, from .75 to #4. Two to three of each for the #2, & #3 sizes should work.  If you have the right size mitts, the whole thing is cruiser ;)

A .5 Camalot could protect the traverse at start if desired.

Two bolt anchor slung with webbing.
content.location: Right side of the wall. Left of The Campaigner, right of Chota Boy.

content.description: In a right facing corner with a wandering secondary crack in the left wall. The Far Left begins wide and can swallow your shoulder. The secondary crack to the left provides a good beginning with hand jams and stems until the crack in the corner is a comfortable size. There are sections up higher where a sharp texture seems to be plastered just outside of the crack.
content.protection: #3 and #4 for the beginning and then #1s the rest the way. Anchors up top.
content.location: The approach trail passes this climb just as it meets up with the cliff. The wall changes directions here and the corner formed is The Far Left.

content.description: Starts with a short section of thin fingers liebacking and really slick feet. Crack widens to tight hands to hands with feet features on the right. After 50 feet, the crack sharply arcs to the right and and passes through a bulge before finishing with good hands. This transition section has some feet on the face but good hand jams. Just run for it! The anchors can also service a offwidth climb to the right. (Too Close to Call, 5.10 ?)
content.location: ~150 feet right of The Far Left. Located behind and slightly to the left of a free standing pillar.

content.description: Not exactly sure of route name, but does not appear to be in Bloom. Begins with broken and slightly loose climbing for the first half, up to a rounded ledge. Immediately off the ledge work your way through a pod with only marginal hands (steep, crux) and then jam a clean, right leaning hands crack to the anchors
content.protection: Pair of rings for anchors up top. First half can take several sizes from .5 to #2 and second half takes #1 and #2.
content.location: First route left of "The Far Left", though some routes exist even farther left on this wall. The approach trail joins the wall at these two climbs where the wall forms a corner.

content.description:
A three pitch rim route. The final pitch climbs the long upper splitter visible from the ground.

P1 climbs the wide corner. 1-2 #6 camelots and a pair of pants are nice here. Belay is two bolts on a ledge left of the corner 5.10

P2 Leave the big gear on the anchor and follow the fingers/tips crack on the left. Bring a very small cam for where the crack pinches down (we used a red X4) and be prepared to crimp a bit. 5.11

P3 The $$$ pitch! Climb 42 meters of splitter hands. The top is a little sandy and there is one larger block to beware of, climb carefully near it. Belay on top of this pitch is gear and takes .4-#1 camelots.

The top rap station is located just to the climber's right of where P3 tops out. Follow cairns up and right to find it. From there, rap the route. The first rappel is an absolute stretcher with a single 80M rope and is probably best done with double 60M ropes.
content.protection:
Pitch1âDoubles #3-#4 camelot, 1-2x #6 camelots to bump.

Pitch 2âSingles very small to #2, extra .4-.5.

Pitch 3âLots of 2's and 1's. A few 3's and .75s, 1x .5 for the top.

content.description: Fun short finger crack with plenty of pods for feet!
content.protection: Doubles of .75 - .3 BD C4 would sew it up.
content.location: About 100' left of Stairway to Heaven. Starts next to a small cave with 20' of easy scrambling to gain the crack.

content.description: A clean right facing dihedral that is mostly thin hand and hands with a short finger section to the anchor.
content.protection: .5 to #2 Camalots.  Extra hands and thin hands size.  Anchor is two angles with webbing.
content.location: About 100'-150' left of "Spider Pig of the Desert"

content.description: The crux is in the area about 20' up where the pro runs out and then there is 2 bolts of tricky corner and crimp jessery. This route has it all, tips, hands, chimney, sport jessery. A bit of "new wave" that actually isn't 5.13.
content.protection: The route is 6' to the right of "Imagine .11+" which is in the new "Bloom" book. The start looks like a right facing corner that goes from tips to nothing in about 20', then you can easily see the 2 bolts.
content.location:
1-silver tcu

2or3 purple tcu

2-blue tcu

2-.4 cams

1-.5 cam

1-.75 cam

2or3 #1 cams

2-#2 cams

1-#3 cam

2 quickdraws for bolts

The anchor is a bolt and fixed #1 cam which will be replaced with a bolt in the future.
